et: Middle English {it}tempeste,{/it} borrowed from Anglo-French, going back to Vulgar Latin {it}*tempesta,{/it} replacing Latin {it}tempestāt-, tempestās{/it} "stretch of time, period, season, weather, stormy weather," from {it}tempes-,{/it} base of {it}tempor-, tempus{/it} (alternative stem {it}temper-{/it}) "time, period of time, season" + {it}-tāt-, -tās,{/it} noun suffix {ma}{mat|tempo|}{/ma}

The proto-Romance form{it} *tempesta{/it} is probably a nominal derivative from the feminine of an adjective {it}tempestus,{/it} cited by the Roman grammarian Sextus Pompeius Festus as an old variant of {it}tempestīvus{/it} "in season, occurring at the proper time."

dt: {bc}to raise a tempest in or around

shortdef: to raise a tempest in or around

dt: {bc}a great commotion over an unimportant matter

shortdef: a great commotion over an unimportant matter

dt: {bc}a situation in which people are upset or angry about something that is not very important

shortdef: a situation in which people are upset or angry about something that is not very important
